lessonOverview.title: Unit 6 - Lesson 1
structures: A: Do you play the cello?
B: Yes, I do. / No, I don’t.
A: Does he/she play the violin?
B: Yes, he/she does. / No, he/she doesn’t.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six instruments (guitar, flute, violin, cello, piano, drums) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Show instrument flashcards or SB visuals. Say: “This is a violin.” Students repeat and match or mime playing the instrument.
stretchStrategies: After practicing “Do you play…?” and “Does he/she play…?”, challenge students to swap roles and form new questions using different pronouns (e.g., “Do they play the piano?” / “Yes, they do.”). Encourage them to create mini conversations in pairs that include two or more instruments.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple questions about playing instruments using “Do you play the...?” / “Does he/she play the...?” and respond with “Yes, I do.” / “No, I don’t.” or “Yes, he/she does.” / “No, he/she doesn’t.”
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Ask: “Do you play the piano?” Students respond “Yes, I do.” or “No, I don’t.” Practise in pairs using flashcards or gestures.
stretchStrategies: After practicing “Do you play…?” and “Does he/she play…?”, challenge students to swap roles and form new questions using different pronouns (e.g., “Do they play the piano?” / “Yes, they do.”). Encourage them to create mini conversations in pairs that include two or more instruments.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “Do you play the ___?” / “Yes, I do.” / “No, I don’t.” and “Does he/she play the ___?” / “Yes, he/she does.” / “No, he/she doesn’t.” to talk about instruments.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write model questions/answers: “Do you play the ___?” / “Does she play the ___?” Students take turns asking and answering with partners.
stretchStrategies: After practicing “Do you play…?” and “Does he/she play…?”, challenge students to swap roles and form new questions using different pronouns (e.g., “Do they play the piano?” / “Yes, they do.”). Encourage them to create mini conversations in pairs that include two or more instruments.

items: Bạn có thích ăn bánh mì không? >> you like eat bread? [do you like to eat bánh mì?]
Con không thích >> I no/not like [I don't like]
Playground words tend to be long and phonetically difficult (slide, see-saw, swings, climbing frame)
Some sports not well known in VN (baseball, cricket, rugby, paragliding, water skiing)
A wide variety of syllabus hobbies may be less popular or available to some Vietnamese students (practising the flute; seeing famous paintings), although many overlap

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.
Bạn muốn ăn gì? >> you want to eat what? [what do you want to eat?]
This is extremely difficult to master, especially combined with do-support.
